'''Tilbury Fort''', also known historically as the '''Thermitage Bulwark''' and the '''West Tilbury Blockhouse''', is an artillery fort on the north bank of the [[River Thames]] in England. The earliest version of the fort, comprising a small [[blockhouse]] with artillery covering the river, was constructed by King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] to protect London against attack from France as part of his [[Device fort|Device programme]]. It was reinforced during the 1588 [[Spanish Armada]] invasion scare, after which it was reinforced with earthwork [[bastion]], and [[Roundheads|Parliamentary forces]] used it to help secure the capital during the [[English Civil War]] of the 1640s. Following naval raids during the [[Anglo-Dutch Wars]], the fort was enlarged by Sir [[Bernard de Gomme]] from 1670 onwards to form a star-shaped defensive work, with angular [[bastion]]s, water-filled [[moat]]s and two lines of guns facing onto the river.
In addition to protecting the Thames, in the 18th century Tilbury also began to be used a transit depot and for storing [[gunpowder]]. It continued to be essential for the defence of the capital and a new [[artillery battery]] was added in the south-east corner during the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. The fort became increasingly less significant as a defensive structure, however, as [[military technology]] developed in the 19th century. It was redeveloped to hold heavy artillery after 1868, providing a second-line of defence along the river, but further changes in technology meant that it had become obsolete by the end of the century. Instead Tilbury became a strategic depot, forming a logistical hub for storing and moving troops and materiel throughout the [[First World War]]. The fort had only a limited role in the [[Second World War]] and was demobilised in 1950.
Tilbury Fort is now operated by the heritage agency [[English Heritage]] as a tourist attraction, receiving 16,154 visitors in 2014.<ref name=VisitBritain/> Many of the more modern military features were demolished during the 1950s, with further restoration work taking place during the 1970s ahead of the site opening to the public in 1983. The 17th-century defences are considered by the historian Paul Pattison to be the "best surviving example of their kind in Britain", and the fort includes the only surviving early 18th century gunpowder [[Magazine (artillery)|magazines]] in Britain.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=9}}</ref>
==History==
===16th century=== [[File:Plan of West Tilbury Blockhouse.png|thumb|Plan of the early Tudor blockhouse]] The first permanent fortification at [[Tilbury]] in [[Essex]] was built as a consequence of international tensions between England, [[Kingdom of France|France]] and the [[Holy Roman Empire]] in the final years of the reign of King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]. Traditionally [[the Crown]] had left coastal defences to the local lords and communities, only taking a modest role in building and maintaining fortifications, and while France and the Empire remained in conflict with one another, maritime raids were common but an actual invasion of England seemed unlikely.<ref>{{harvnb|Thompson|1987|p=111}}; {{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=63}}</ref> Basic defences, based around simple [[blockhouse]]s and towers, existed in the south-west and along the [[Sussex]] coast, with a few more impressive works in the north of England, but in general the fortifications were very limited in scale.<ref>{{harvnb|King|1991|pp=176–177}}</ref>
In 1533, Henry broke with Pope [[Paul III]] in order to annul the long-standing marriage to his wife, [[Catherine of Aragon]], and remarry.<ref>{{harvnb|Morley|1976|p=7}}</ref> Catherine was the aunt of [[Charles V of Spain|Charles V]], the Holy Roman Emperor, and he took the annulment as a personal insult.<ref>{{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=63}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=5}}</ref> This resulted in France and the Empire declaring an alliance against Henry in 1538, and the Pope encouraging the two countries to attack England.<ref>{{harvnb|Morley|1976|p=7}}; {{harvnb|Hale|1983|pp=63–64}}</ref> An invasion of England appeared certain.<ref>{{harvnb|Hale|1983|p=66}}; {{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=6}}</ref> In response, Henry issued an order, called a "[[Device Fort|device]]", in 1539, giving instructions for the "defence of the realm in time of invasion" and the construction of forts along the English coastline.<ref>{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=11}}; {{harvnb|Walton|2010|p=70}}</ref>
The [[River Thames]] was strategically important, as the city of London and the newly constructed royal dockyards of [[Deptford Dockyard|Deptford]] and [[Woolwich Dockyard|Woolwich]] were vulnerable to seaborne attacks arriving up the estuary, which was a major maritime route, carrying 80 percent of England's exports.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|1980|p=342}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1989|p=42}}</ref> At the mouth of the estuary, the Thames narrowed considerably, forming a natural hub for communications: the "Long Ferry" took passengers into the capital, and the "[[Gravesend–Tilbury Ferry|Cross Ferry]]" moved traffic across the river.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1989|p=42}}; {{harvnb|Kent Council|2004|p=8}}; {{harvnb|Smith|1980|p=341}}</ref> This was also the first point that an invasion force would be able to easily disembark along the Thames, as before this point the [[mudflat]]s along the sides of the estuary would have made landings difficult.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|1974|p=142}}</ref> Temporary defences had been constructed at Tilbury as early as the 14th and 15th centuries, although little is known about their design.<ref name=MooreP7>{{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=7}}</ref>
[[File:Gravesend defences 1588 Thamesis Descriptio.png|thumb|300px|left|19th-century copy of 1588 engraving, showing the defences along the [[River Thames]], including Tilbury Fort (centre) and the [[boom (navigational barrier)|boom]]]] Under the King's new programme of work, the Thames was protected with a mutually reinforcing network of blockhouses at [[Gravesend Blockhouse|Gravesend]], [[Milton Blockhouse|Milton]], and [[Higham Blockhouse|Higham]] on the south side of the river, and West and East Tilbury on the opposite bank.<ref>{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=20}}</ref> West Tilbury Blockhouse, part of the inner line, was initially called the "Thermitage Bulwark", because it was on the site of a [[hermitage (religious retreat)|hermitage]] [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|dissolved]] by the King in 1536.<ref name=EH>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=19}}; {{harvnb|Smith|1980|p=342}}</ref> It was designed by James Nedeham and [[Christopher Morice]], supported by three overseers; prior to the work, the estimated cost had been given as £211, allowing for stone, timber, 150,000 bricks and {{convert|200|t}} of chalk.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|1980|pp=344-345}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=154}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=9}}</ref>{{efn|name=Money16thC|Comparing early modern costs and prices with those of the modern period is challenging. £211 in 1539 could equate to between £118,900 and £54,140,000, depending on the price comparison used. For comparison, the total royal expenditure on all the Device Forts across England between 1539–47 came to £376,500, with St Mawes, for example, costing £5,018, and Sandgate £5,584. £305 in 1588 could equate to between £921,000 and £26 million, and £47,000 in 1670 to between £92 million and £1,500 million.<ref>{{harvnb|Biddle|Hiller|Scott|Streeten|2001|p=12}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/ | title=Five Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a UK Pound Amount, 1270 to Present| author1 = Lawrence H. Officer | author2= Samuel H. Williamson| postscript =none | mode = cs2|date = 2014| accessdate=29 May 2015 | publisher=MeasuringWorth}}</ref>}} The D-shaped blockhouse was curved at the front, with two storeys of [[gun-port]]s, and probably had additional gun platforms stretching along the river on either side of it; ancillary buildings were placed at the rear and the whole site was protected by a [[rampart (fortification)|rampart]] and a ditch, with extensive [[marshland]]s and [[creek (stream)|creek]]s giving additional protection to the east.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|pp=154-155}}; {{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=16}}</ref> It was initially commanded by Captain Francis Grant and his deputy, and garrisoned with a porter, two soldiers and four gunners, equipped with up to five [[List of medieval and early modern gunpowder artillery|artillery]] pieces including a [[demi-cannon]] and [[saker (cannon)|saker]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=154}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=9}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=21}}</ref>
The invasion threat passed and in 1553 all of the blockhouses were ordered to return their guns; Milton and Higham were demolished.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|1980|p=347}}</ref> In the summer of 1588, however, there was a fresh threat of invasion by the [[Spanish Armada]].<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=155}}</ref> An army was mobilised to protect the mouth of the estuary and emergency improvements to the fortifications at Tilbury Blockhouse were made by [[Robert Dudley, 1st Earl of Leicester|Rober Dudley]], the [[Earl of Leicester]].<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=155}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=9}}</ref> Queen Elizabeth I visited the fort by barge on 8 August 1588 and rode in procession to the nearby army camp, where she gave a [[Speech to the Troops at Tilbury|speech]] to the assembled forces.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=20}}; {{harvnb|Cruden|1843|pp=251-253}}</ref> Fears of invasion continued even after the defeat of the Armada, and over the course of the next year the Italian engineer, [[Federigo Giambelli]], reinforced the blockhouse with probably two [[concentric]] [[Earthworks (engineering)|earthwork]] ramparts, with [[Ditch (fortification)|ditch]]es and a [[palisade]].<ref name=Saunders19601977Moore1990>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|pp=155-156}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=10}}; {{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=7}}</ref> A [[boom (navigational barrier)|boom]] was stretched across the river to Gravesend at a cost of £305.<ref name=Saunders19601977Moore1990/>{{efn|name=Money16thC}}
===17th century=== [[File:De Gomme's map of Tilbury Fort, 1670.png|thumb|[[Bernard de Gomme]]'s original plan for the redesigned fort, 1670]] In the early 1600s, England was at peace with France and Spain and as a result the coastal defences received little attention; surveys reported multiple problems with Tilbury Fort including flooding caused by the estuary tides, and ferry passengers and animals making their way uninvited into the fort.<ref>{{harvnb|Harrington|2007|p=49}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1989|pp=70–71}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=10}}</ref> In 1642 [[English Civil War|civil war]] broke out between the supporters of King Charles I and those of [[Roundheads|Parliament]]. Tilbury was controlled by Parliament, who placed the Tilbury and Gravesend forts under the command of a military governor, using them to control traffic entering London and to search for spies; it saw no military action during the war.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|1974|pp=153–154}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=10}}</ref> Tilbury remained in use during the interregnum, having a garrison of three officers and sixty-six men in 1651.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=10}}</ref>
After [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] was restored to the throne in 1660, he began a wide-ranging programme of work on the coastal defences.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=158}}</ref> The Dutch fleet then attacked up the Thames in June 1667, but were deterred from going further for fear of the Tilbury and Gravesend fortifications.<ref name=Smith1964PP154>{{harvnb|Smith|1974|pp=154–155}}</ref> In reality, the forts were poorly prepared to resist a Dutch attack; at Tilbury there were only two guns ready for action.<ref name=Smith1964PP154/> The Dutch [[Raid on the Medway|struck the English fleet]] at [[Medway]] instead, giving enough time for the government to improve the defences along the Thames and mount 80 guns on the forts.<ref name=Smith1964PP154/> In the wake of the conflict, the King instructed his Chief Engineer, a Dutchman called Sir [[Bernard de Gomme]], to develop Tilbury Fort's defences further.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=159}}</ref>
[[File:Tilbury Fort - Drawbridges - geograph.org.uk - 1640071.jpg|thumb|left|The 17th-century [[ravelin]], [[drawbridge]]s and the inner [[moat]]]] De Gomme prepared several plans for the King in 1665; a further iteration of the designs was submitted in 1670 and given royal approval.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=166}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=11}}</ref> Work began the same year butit took until 1685 to complete the project.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=23}}</ref> The work was carried out by skilled contractors, who were supplemented by large teams of [[Impressment|pressed men]] brought in from across the region; during 1671, up to 256 workers were employed on the site.<ref name=Saunders1977P11>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=11}}</ref> Around 3,000 timber [[Deep foundation|piles]] had to be brought from Norway for the project in 1671 to support the foundations in the marshy ground.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=162}}</ref> The resources needed for the King's multiple defence projects became stretched, and one of the planned bastions at Tilbury, originally planned to face the river, was cancelled in 1681, in part to save money.<ref name=Saunders1960P163>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=163}}</ref> The total cost of the project is unknown, but was significantly more than the original estimate of £47,000.<ref name=Saunders1960P163/>{{efn|name=Money16thC}}
The result was a large, five-sided, star-shaped fort with four angular bastions, [[Revetment|revetted]] in brick, with an outer curtain of defences, including two moats and a [[redoubt]]; two new [[gatehouse]]s defended the entrance from the north.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|pp=11-13}}; {{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=7}}</ref> Two gun lines of gun platforms, facing the river, stretched alongside either the side of the fort.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=13}}</ref> The Henrician blockhouse was incorporated into the defences, but the Elizabethan earthworks were destroyed.<ref name=Saunders1977P11/> The interior of the fort was raised up above the level of the marshes to prevent flooding, and barracks and other buildings were constructed inside.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=23}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=163}}</ref> The writer [[John Evelyn]] praised the new fort as "a Royal work indeede".<ref name=Saunders1960P163/> Further work after 1694 replaced the wooden gun platforms alongside the river with more durable stone equivalents.<ref name=Saunders1960P164>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=164}}</ref> {{-}} ===18th–19th centuries=== [[File:Late 18th century cannon at Tilbury Fort.jpg|thumb|Late 18th-century cannon on the bastion walls]] By the start of the 18th century, Tilbury Fort was one of the most powerful in Britain.<ref>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|p=25}}</ref> The number of artillery guns varied; in 1715 there were 17 demi-cannon and 26 [[culverin]]s mounted on the west gun platform, and 31 demi-cannons and one culverin on the east; the following year there were reported to be 161 guns in total at the fort, although 92 of these were in poor repair and inoperable.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|pp=14-15}}</ref>
In addition to its role in protecting the Thames, the fort had various military uses during the 18th century. From 1716 onwards, the [[Board of Ordnance]] began to use it as a [[gunpowder]] [[depot]]; there were safety restrictions on moving gunpowder in and out of the London docks, so Tilbury was used instead.<ref>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|pp=26-27}}; {{cite web|url= https://content.historicengland.org.uk/images-books/publications/greater-thames-estuary-res-framework-2010/gt-research-framework-2010-pt1.pdf|publisher=Essex County Council, Historic Environment Branch|title=The Greater Thames Estuary Historic Environment Research Framework: Update and Revision of the Archaeological Research Framework for the Greater Thames Estuary (1999)|date=2010|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016|page=78}}</ref> Two large [[magazine (artillery)|magazines]] were built, able to hold 3,600 barrels of powder each, and the old blockhouse and other buildings were converted to act as further magazines.<ref>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|p=27}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=164}}</ref> Eventually the fort could hold more than 19,000 barrels of gunpowder.<ref name=Pattison2004P27>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|p=27}}</ref> It was also used as a transit depot for soldiers and, after the [[Jacobite rising of 1745]], as a prison to hold 268 [[Scottish Highlands|Highlander]] prisoners of war.<ref name=Saunders1960P164/> The Jacobite prisoners were kept in the gunpowder magazines and 45 died from [[typhus]] before they were sent on to London for trial.<ref>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|p=26}}</ref>
The living conditions at the fort were poor.<ref name=Saunders1960P164/> It was surrounded by marshes, with a poor road network, and the garrison had to survive on collected [[rainwater]].<ref name=Saunders1960P164/> A trader called a [[sutler]] built a house inside the southern entrance, growing vegetables within the south-west bastion and enjoying an effective monopoly on selling food to the soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/archiveDS/archiveDownload?t=arch-265-1/dissemination/pdf/tf195/tf195.pdf|title=Excavations at Tilbury Fort, Essex|author=M. Beasley|date=1995|accessdate=28 May 2016|mode=cs2|p=4}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=6}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1021092|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}; {{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=16}}</ref> New [[barracks]] for the officers and enlisted men were rebuilt in 1772, but the officers often preferred to live across the river in the more urban setting of Gravesend, near the military headquarters there.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=14-15}}</ref> A cricket match in 1776 between men from the Kentish and Essex sides of the Thames reportedly ended in bloodshed when guns were seized from the guardroom; newspapers recounted how an Essex man and a sergeant were shot dead, and a soldier was bayonetted, before both sides fled the scene.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=18}}</ref> It is uncertain how accurate the newspaper account was, although the historians [[Andrew Saunders]] and Charles Kightly give it some credence.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=18}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/learn/story-of-england/georgians/1780939/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529094736/http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/learn/story-of-england/georgians/1780939/ |archive-date=29 May 2016|title = The Only People Ever Killed at Tilbury Fort|author=Charles Kightly|publisher=English History|access-date=22 May 2015|mode=cs2}}</ref>
[[File:Copper doors at Tilbury Fort.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Early 18th-century [[copper]] doors on the magazines]] During the [[American Revolutionary War]] there were fears of a French attack on London.<ref name=Pattison2004P27/> In 1780, the Army carried out a practice attack on the fort with 5,000 soldiers, but there were less than 60 guns left at the fort and many of these were in poor condition.<ref>{{harvnb|Osborne|2013|p=59}}</ref> [[Thomas Hyde Page]] inspected Tilbury in 1788 and reported that the defences facing the Thames were seriously inadequate.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=14}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=27}}</ref> As a consequence, a new battery was built in the south-east corner of the defences, armed with 32-pounders (14.5 kg) pointing down-river, and a new battery, [[New Tavern Fort]], was built along the river to the east.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=14}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=165}}; {{harvnb|Osborne|2013|p=62}}</ref> Fears continued during the [[French Revolutionary]] and [[Napoleonic Wars]] and smaller batteries were constructed further up the river in 1794.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|pp=165-166}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=27}}</ref> Tilbury continued to be an essential part of the capital's defences because of its control of the crossing point on the Thames, and the guns were upgraded with new traversing platforms; the Gravesend Volunteer Artillery was formed to man the forts on both sides of the river.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=166}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=27}}; {{harvnb|Osborne|2013|p=61}}</ref> During the invasion scare of 1803, the Royal Trinity House Volunteer Artillery manned ten armed [[Hulk (ship type)|hulks]] placed across the river as a barrier at Tilbury.<ref>{{harvnb|Osborne|2013|p=61}}</ref>
The size of the garrison varied during the first half of the century, but in 1830 the fort had space for 15 officers and 150 enlisted men.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=15}}</ref> Despite the construction of a new range of facilities in 1809, the living conditions of the soldiers remained poor, with four men sharing each of the two-bed rooms in the barracks, and no running water on the site.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=15}}; {{harnvb|Pattison|2004|pp=6-7}}</ref> During the 19th century, a pump was installed to bring water up from a well {{convert|178|m}} below the surface.<ref>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|p=10}}</ref> Nationwide investigations into the standard of Army barracks during 1857 led to investment in better facilities at Tilbury; piped water was run into the site in 1877, and improved amenities and sanitation were installed after 1880.<ref>{{harnvb|Pattison|2004|pp=7, 10}}</ref>
[[File:Detail from Clarkson Stanfield - Tilbury Fort--Wind Against the Tide - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|''Tilbury Fort- Wind Against Tide'' by [[Clarkson Stanfield]], showing Tilbury Fort (left) and [[Coalhouse Fort]] (right) in 1853]] By the 1850s, the advent of steam ships meant that enemy vessels could sail up the Thames far more quickly than before, reducing the time available for forts to intercept them.<ref name="moore8">{{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=8}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=28}}</ref> Rifled guns and turret-mounted weapons and new armour-plating meant that enemy warships could fire on forts such as Tilbury from downstream more easily while being protected from their guns.<ref name="moore8"/> Fears of an potential invasion by [[Napoleon III of France]] led to the establishment [[Royal Commission on the Defence of the United Kingdom]] in 1859.<ref name=Pattison2004P28>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=28}}</ref> The Commission reported the following year and recommended that new, more powerful forts be built further downstream, with defences such as Tilbury Fort forming a second-line of defence.<ref name=Pattison2004P28/> Work began on strengthening Tilbury in 1868, under the direction of the then Captain [[Charles George Gordon|Charles Gordon]], focusing on adding heavier gun positions able to fire upstream to support the new forts.<ref name="saunders172">{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=172}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=28}}</ref> The west, north-east and east bastions and the south-east curtain wall were altered to house thirteen [[Rifled muzzle loader|rifled muzzle-loading guns]], protected by brick walls, earthworks and iron shields.<ref name="saunders172"/> Initially 7-ton, 7-inch (7,112 kg, 17 cm) guns were deployed but these were upgraded to 9-inch ((22 cm) weapons by 1888, supported by a heavier 25-ton, 11-inch (25,401 kg, 27 cm) gun.<ref name="saunders172"/> The old Tudor block-house was destroyed to make way for the new guns.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=172}}</ref>
Naval and defensive technology continued to improve over the next few decades, rendering Tilbury Fort's bastion design out-moded.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=173}}</ref> The government considered the defences further down the Thames to be sufficient and Tilbury was therefore not improved; it was largely redundant as a defensive fortification by the end of the century, although still in use as a strategic depot.<ref>{{harvnb|Moore|1990|p=4}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1960|p=173}}</ref> From 1889 onwards it formed a [[London Defence Positions|mobilisation centre]] to support a mobile strike force in the event of an invasion, part of the wider London Defence Scheme, and large storage buildings were built across the site to store materiel.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|pp=29-30}}</ref>
===20th–21st centuries=== [[File:Gun - geograph.org.uk - 334784.jpg|thumb|A Mark V [[QF 12-pounder 12 cwt naval gun|quick-firing 12-pounder, 12 cwt (5.4 kg, 50.8 kg) gun]] on the south-eastern curtain]] Fresh concerns grew that the Thames might be vulnerable to attack from [[torpedo boat]]s and [[armoured cruiser]]s, and in 1903 four [[QF 12-pounder 12 cwt naval gun|quick-firing 12-pounder, 12 cwt (5.4 kg, 50.8 kg) guns]] were positioned on Tilbury's south-east curtain wall, supplemented in 1904 by two [[BL 6 inch gun Mk II – VI|6-inch (15 cm) breech loading guns]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thurrock.gov.uk/historical-places-in-thurrock/tilbury-fort-during-world-war-one|title=Tilbury Fort during World War One|publisher=Thurrock Council|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315100222/https://www.thurrock.gov.uk/historical-places-in-thurrock/tilbury-fort-during-world-war-one |archive-date=15 March 2016| accessdate=27 May 2016|mode=cs2}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|pp=16, 29}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.victorianforts.co.uk/pdf/datasheets/tilbury.pdf|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Victorian Forts|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> In 1905, however, the government decided that the [[Royal Navy]] and the forts downstream gave sufficient protection for the capital and removed the artillery, leaving only machine-guns in place.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=29}}</ref>
Tilbury continued to function as a mobilisation store and, after the outbreak of the First World War, it was used to house up to 300 transit soldiers and to supply the new army camps established at [[Purfleet]] and [[Belhus, Essex|Belhus Mansion]].<ref name="thurrock30">{{cite web|url=https://www.thurrock.gov.uk/historical-places-in-thurrock/tilbury-fort-during-world-war-one|title=Tilbury Fort during World War One|publisher=Thurrock Council|accessdate=27 May 2016|mode=cs2}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=30}}</ref> It was initially manned by the 2nd Battalion of the [[Royal Dublin Fusiliers]] until 1916, and by various reserve units for the rest of the war.<ref>{{harvnb|Osborne|2013|p=94}}</ref> The fort itself was used to store munitions while a depot for remounts was built just to the west; a [[pontoon bridge]] was built across the Thames for troop movements, guarded by the fort's guns.<ref>{{harvnb|Osborne|2013|pp=94, 107}}</ref> Until 1917, also used to house the headquarters of several infantry battalions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thurrock.gov.uk/historical-places-in-thurrock/tilbury-fort-during-world-war-one|title=Tilbury Fort during World War One|publisher=Thurrock Council|accessdate=27 May 2016|mode=cs2}}</ref> Electric lighting was installed, and a [[narrow-gauge railway]] and a steam crane on the quay were added to help to move material in and out of the fort.<ref name="thurrock30"/> After the [[Zeppelin]] raids of June 1915, anti-aircraft guns and searchlights mounted at the fort and they played a role in the shooting down of the German Navy Zeppelin, ''L15'', although it is disputed as to which site in the area fired the shell that brought down the airship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thurrock.gov.uk/historical-places-in-thurrock/tilbury-fort-during-world-war-one|title=Tilbury Fort during World War One|publisher=Thurrock Council|accessdate=27 May 2016|mode=cs2}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=30}}; {{harvnb|Fegan|2002|p=29}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=18}}</ref>
During the [[inter-war years]], the government concluded that the fort was no longer militarily useful and there were unsuccessful attempts to sell it off for development.<ref name=Pattison2004P31>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=31}}</ref> During the [[Second World War]], the fort initially housed an improvised anti-aircraft operations room, controlling the defences of the Thames and Medway (North) Gun Zone between 1939 and 1940.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=18}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=31}}</ref> Trenches were dug across the surrounding area to prevent an airborne attack.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=30}}</ref> The enlisted barracks and the facilities block, as well as probably the sutler's house, were bombed and damaged, being demolished after the war.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/archiveDS/archiveDownload?t=arch-265-1/dissemination/pdf/tf195/tf195.pdf|title=Excavations at Tilbury Fort, Essex|author=M. Beasley|date=1995|accessdate=28 May 2016|mode=cs2|p=4}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=6}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1021092|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> The fort was transferred out of military use relatively early in the post-war period, and in 1950 the [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]] took over the site.<ref>{{harvnb|Chapple|2014|p=17}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=31}}</ref> Restoration work took place in the 1970, including the construction of replica wooden bridges.<ref name=Pattison2004P31/> It was opened to the public in 1982.<ref name=Pattison2004P31/>
In the 21st century, the fort is controlled by [[English Heritage]] and operated as a tourist attraction, receiving 16,154 visitors in 2014.<ref name=VisitBritain>{{cite web|url=http://d1myqg1v1ynzrd.cloudfront.net/sites/default/files/vb-corporate/Documents-Library/documents/England-documents/full_attractions_listing_for_publication_v5-1.xlsx|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529094504/http://d1myqg1v1ynzrd.cloudfront.net/sites/default/files/vb-corporate/Documents-Library/documents/England-documents/full_attractions_listing_for_publication_v5-1.xlsx |archive-date=29 May 2016|title=2014 Full Attractions Listing|publisher=Visit Britain|date=2014|mode=cs2|access-date=22 May 2015}}</ref> The site is protected under UK law as a [[scheduled ancient monument]], with the officers' barracks a grade II* [[listed building]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1021092|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1375568|title=Officers Barracks, Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref>
==Architecture== Tilbury Fort remains largely unaltered from its reconstruction in the late 17th century under the direction of Sir Bernard de Gomme, with some 19th century additions.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=5}}</ref> It was designed in a predominantly Dutch style, with a ring of outer and inner defences intended to allow the fort to attack hostile warships, while being protected from attack from the land.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1021092|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=5}}</ref> The heritage agency [[Historic England]] describes it as "England's most spectacular" example of a late 17th century fort, and the historian Paul Pattison considers the defences the "best surviving example of their kind in Britain".<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=9}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1021092|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref>
===Outer defences=== [[File:Tilbury Fort, modern plan.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Plan of the fort; A - redan; B - outer defences and covered way; C - ravelin; D - outer moat; E - inner moat; F - Landport Gate; G - The World's End public house; H - magazines; I - officer's quarters; J - Water Gate, chapel and guard House; K - quick-firing emplacements; L - 6-inch (15 cm) gun emplacements; M - West Gun Line; N - quay; P - East Gun Line]] The outer defences comprise outer and inner water-filled moats, fed by the Thames and separated by a ring of defensive ramparts.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=9}}</ref> The inner moat is {{convert|50|m}} wide but relatively shallow and the banks have been repeatedly strengthened with piles to protect them from erosion.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=21}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1021092|title=Tilbury Fort|publisher=Historic England|mode=cs2|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> The fort is entered from the north through a triangular defensive work known as a [[redan]], with a [[redoubt]] to defend the entrance.<ref name=Saunders1977P19>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=19}}</ref> A [[causeway]] links the redan to the outer defences, which form a complex pattern of ramparts, protecting a covered way stretching around the defensive line.<ref name=Saunders1977P19/> There are bastions on the north-west and north-east corners, and two triangular spurs, originally equipped with cannons, project from the defences on the west and east sides, with assembly points for infantry soldiers on the inside.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|pp=19-20}}</ref>
A replica wooden bridge runs from the outer defences over the water to an island called a [[ravelin]], which is in turn linked to the inner defences by another replica bridge, protected with two [[drawbridge]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=10}}</ref> The ravelin formed a physical barrier to incoming artillery fire aimed at the entrance to the inner defences and could also have directed fire against enemy forces that breached the outer defensive line.<ref name=Saunders1977P21>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=21}}</ref>
On the south side of the outer defences, facing the river, are the West and East Lines of gun positions. These were built in the 18th century and have been subject to considerable [[erosion]] and [[silting]]; 12 of the original 14 gun positions on the West Line remain but only one of the East Line has survived.<ref name=Saunders1977P19/> In between the lines is a quay, designed to allow the delivery of supplies from the Thames, and the remains of the tracks from the narrow gauge railway built during the First World War.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|pp=19, 26}}</ref> A [[sluice gate]] in the south-west corner managed the water in the moats, and allowed them to be drained completely should the surfaces begin to freeze over in winter and provide an advantage to any attackers.<ref name=Saunders1977P21/> To the west of the outer defences is the World's End pub, originally the local ferry house, dating from 1788.<ref name=Saunders1977P19/>
===Inner defences=== The inner defences largely follow a pentagonal design, with four defensive bastions positioned around a central [[parade ground]]. From the south, the fort is entered through the Water Gate. This two-storeyed gatehouse dates from the late 17th century with a monumental stone facade featuring carved displays of [[Classical antiquity|classical]] and 17th-century weapons; when first built, the now-empty niche at the front probably held a statue of King Charles II.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=23}}; {{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=17}}</ref> The building originally acted a house for the master gunner.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=23}}</ref> Most of the inside of the fort is taken up by the parade ground, an area covering {{convert|2.5|acre}}.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=26}}</ref> The central parade ground was raised to its current height in the 17th and 19th centuries using chalk and dirt, and by the early 20th century much of it was occupied by four large warehouses, since destroyed.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=5}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=26}}</ref>
[[File:Tilbury Fort - Parade ground - geograph.org.uk - 1640070.jpg|thumb|left|The parade ground, with the foundations of the soldiers' barracks in the foreground]] Moving east from the Water Gate, the south-eastern curtain defences and the south-east bastion were rebuilt at the start of the 20th century to hold emplacements for four quick-firing guns and two 6-inch (15 cm) guns, with underground tunnels linking to an underground magazine.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|pp=15-16}}</ref> Four artillery pieces, dating from 1898 to 1942, are on display.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=16}}</ref> Facing the parade ground are the officers' quarters, a terrace of houses probably dating in its current form to the late 18th century, with a stables at the northern end, originally used to hold the commandant's horses.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=15}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=25}}</ref> It now holds the Bernard Truss collection of military memorabilia.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=15}}</ref> The north-east bastion was redesigned after 1868 and contains an earth-covered magazine, as well as emplacements for 9-inch (22 cm) rifled muzzle loading guns.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|pp=12-14}}</ref>
On the north side of the parade are two early 18th century magazines, altered in the 19th century.<ref name=Pattison2004P11>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=11}}</ref> These were specially designed to avoid the use of iron, which might have generated sparks and set off an explosion, instead being built using wood and copper; they are the only remaining examples of their type in Britain.<ref name=Pattison2004P11/> The Landport Gate lies behind the magazines, and has a gatehouse, called the Dead House, above the passageway leading into the interior of the fort.<ref>{{harvnb|Saunders|1977|pp=21, 23}}</ref> Past the north-west bastion, the soldiers' barracks would have stood opposite those of the officers', but was destroyed after the war and only the foundations of the building remain.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=6}}</ref> The south-west magazine also holds a covered magazine, similar to that in the north-east bastion.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|p=33}}</ref> Just to the west of the Water Gate is the fort's guardhouse and [[chapel]], dating from the late 17th century and one of the oldest surviving places of worship within a British artillery fortress.<ref>{{harvnb|Pattison|2004|pp=3-4}}; {{harvnb|Saunders|1977|p=24}}</ref>
